DISCUSSION VACV infection causes cellular mRNA degradation. this degradation occurs through a combined action of VACV-encoded decapping enzymes D9 and D10 and cellular nuclease XRN1. mRNA depletion plays a major role during the VACV-induced host shutoff that results in similar reductions of ribosome-associated cellular mRNAs. oxidative phosphorylation is still a major source of ATP production (43). a study by Fontaine et al. showed that VACV depends more on glutamine than on glucose for efficient replication. oxidative phosphorylation is required when using glutamine as cellular fuel. enterovirus 71 and dengue virus infections cause an oxidative phosphorylation dysfunction in infected cells. impaired oxidative phosphorylation function may be able to provide sufficient energy for some viruses. however, for viruses that need a large amount of energy, the impaired oxidative phosphorylation function could restrict viral replication. a short 5′ UTR in Drosophila is responsible for the higher TE of some oxidative phosphorylation mRNAs under the condition of dietary restriction (55). the 5′ UTRs of early mRNAs vary from 3 to 601 nt, with a median length of 21 nt, while the 5′ UTRs of intermediate and late mRNAs all have a poly(A) leader with a length of up to 51 nt (56, oxidative phosphorylation in mammals involves >100 genes encoded in both the nuclear and mitochondrial genomes. translation of oxidative phosphorylation mRNAs occurs in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria by using two distinct translation systems. mRNAs important in cell maintenance processes such as oxidative phosphorylation are less affected during virus-induced host shutoff. identification of these selectively translated proteins is important to elucidate the functional relevance of and
